data.title: Little Miss Fix-It
data.meta_description:
Song: "The Only Bit of Ireland in Old New York"
	Performer: Nora Bayes and Jack Norworth
	Show: Little Miss Fix-It
	Tryout: 9 March 1911 (Poli’s, Waterbury), 10 March 1911 (Grand O.H., New Haven), 13 March 1911 (Star, Buffalo), 17 March 1911 (Lyceum, Rochester), 20 March 1911 (Chestnut Street O.H., Philadelphia)
	Opening: 3 April 1911 (Globe)
	Tour: 22 May 1911 (Chicago O.H., Chicago), 3 September 1911 (Grand O.H., Cincinnati), 18 September 1911 (Nixon, Pittsburgh), 25 September 1911 (Euclid Avenue O.H., Cleveland), … 5 October 1911 (Faurot, Lima, Oh.), 10 October 1911 (Fairbanks, Springfield, Oh.), 15 October 1911 (Century, St. Louis), … 6 November 1911 (Albert, Chattanooga), …
	Lyrics: Harry B. Smith
	Music: W.J. Hurlbut
	Sheet Music Artist: Standard Engraving Co.
	Publisher: The Norworth Pub. Co.
	
	Nora Bayes and Jack Norworth stayed with the production until St. Louis. Bayes left due to illness, followed at the end of the week by Norworth (who was said not to have got along with Bayes’s replacement, Eva Tanguay). In New Orleans, Tanguay was replaced by Alice Lloyd.
	
	Chicago-born Nora Bayes (1880–1928) began performing in 1898, soon becoming a fixture in vaudeville and on Broadway. Philadelphia-born Jack Norworth (1879–1959) was a noted songwriter as well as performer. Bayes and Norworth married in 1907. The couple toured and recorded many songs. They divorced in 1913. Bayes went on to perform and record through the 1920s. Norworth continued to write and record and made a series of film shorts between 1929 and 1932.
data.text:
Song: "The Only Bit of Ireland in Old New York"

Performer: Nora Bayes and Jack Norworth

Show: Little Miss Fix-It

Tryout: 9 March 1911 (Poli’s, Waterbury), 10 March 1911 (Grand O.H., New Haven), 13 March 1911 (Star, Buffalo), 17 March 1911 (Lyceum, Rochester), 20 March 1911 (Chestnut Street O.H., Philadelphia)

Opening: 3 April 1911 (Globe)

Tour: 22 May 1911 (Chicago O.H., Chicago), 3 September 1911 (Grand O.H., Cincinnati), 18 September 1911 (Nixon, Pittsburgh), 25 September 1911 (Euclid Avenue O.H., Cleveland), … 5 October 1911 (Faurot, Lima, Oh.), 10 October 1911 (Fairbanks, Springfield, Oh.), 15 October 1911 (Century, St. Louis), … 6 November 1911 (Albert, Chattanooga), …

Lyrics: Harry B. Smith

Music: W.J. Hurlbut

Sheet Music Artist: Standard Engraving Co.

Publisher: The Norworth Pub. Co.

Nora Bayes and Jack Norworth stayed with the production until St. Louis. Bayes left due to illness, followed at the end of the week by Norworth (who was said not to have got along with Bayes’s replacement, Eva Tanguay). In New Orleans, Tanguay was replaced by Alice Lloyd.

Chicago-born Nora Bayes (1880–1928) began performing in 1898, soon becoming a fixture in vaudeville and on Broadway. Philadelphia-born Jack Norworth (1879–1959) was a noted songwriter as well as performer. Bayes and Norworth married in 1907. The couple toured and recorded many songs. They divorced in 1913. Bayes went on to perform and record through the 1920s. Norworth continued to write and record and made a series of film shorts between 1929 and 1932.
